message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description fits with fibronectin, which exists in both soluble and insoluble forms and plays a role in connecting integrins to the extracellular matrix. Mutations in fibronectin have been linked to a number of skeletal dysplasias, including early onset scoliosis and multiple fractures. Dermatan sulfate, type 1 collagen, and type 3 collagen are not typically associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the protein being an extracellular matrix protein that links integrins and is involved in clotting suggests Fibronectin, which is involved in both processes. Mutations in Fibronectin are associated with several skeletal disorders, including early onset scoliosis and frequent fractures. None of the other options are involved in both integrin binding and clotting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The insoluble dimer that links integrins to the extracellular matrix suggests fibronectin. Mutations in the fibronectin gene have been associated with early onset scoliosis and multiple fractures. The other options are not typically associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description matches Fibronectin, which exists in both an insoluble and soluble form and helps link integrins to the extracellular matrix. Mutations in Fibronectin can cause skeletal abnormalities such as scoliosis and multiple fractures. The other options do not match the description given.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of early onset scoliosis and multiple fractures suggests a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue. Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein that plays a role in cell adhesion and is associated with disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and Marfan syndrome. The other options do not fit the described functions of the mutated protein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of multiple fractures and short stature suggest a possible connective tissue disorder. Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein that assists with cell adhesion, and mutations in fibronectin have been associated with various connective tissue disorders including scoliosis and multiple fractures. Type 1 and Type 3 collagen mutations are associated with other connective tissue disorders such as osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, but not typically with early onset scoliosis. Dermatan sulfate is a component of proteoglycans, but mutations in dermatan sulfate are not associated with scoliosis or multiple fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extracellular protein described displays characteristics of fibronectin, which exists in both an insoluble dimer form and a soluble form that assists with clotting. Mutations in fibronectin have been associated with skeletal disorders such as early onset scoliosis and fractures, as well as other systemic manifestations. The other options do not match the description of the extracellular protein in question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extracellular protein described in the question is fibronectin, which exists in both a soluble and insoluble form and is linked to integrins and the extracellular matrix. Mutations in fibronectin are associated with a rare genetic disorder called congenital contractural arachnodactyly (CCA), which can cause scoliosis and multiple fractures, among other symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The insoluble dimer form of the protein that links integrins to the extracellular matrix and is linked by disulfide bonds is fibronectin. Mutations in fibronectin have been associated with early onset scoliosis and a history of fractures. The other options listed are not associated with scoliosis or fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the protein suggests that it is fibronectin. Mutations in the gene encoding fibronectin can result in a condition called congenital contractural arachnodactyly or Beals syndrome, which is characterized by short stature, joint contractures, and scoliosis. Fibronectin also helps link integrins to the extracellular matrix through its insoluble dimer form.
